newsitem.title: USA: U.S. cash crude prices retreat in low volume day.
newsitem.headline: U.S. cash crude prices retreat in low volume day.

text.p: Cash crude prices in the U.S. declined over the course of a tepid, dull session ahead of the Memorial Day holiday on technically-inspired selling.
July West Texas Intermediate/Cushing wound out the week 20-25 cents lower at $21.55-65 a barrel.
The last trading day for June outrights saw outrights dip to a 35-40 cents discount against the new prompt July. June grade barrels moved at wide ranges in low volume.
Domestic cash grades strengthened on firmer CFDs, a narrowed Brent-WTI arbitrage and the closure of a key pipeline link connecting U.S. Gulf crude streams to the Capline system.

South Louisiana LOCAP pipeline operations were expected to resume sometime over the weekend, likely by Sunday. A leak was discovered Thursday, forcing the shutting in of some 700,000 barrels per day (bpd) of crude throughput.
LOOP officials said force majeure measures would not be needed, as lost supply would be accounted for over the rest of the month.
For the day, Light Louisiana Sweet/St. James was talked late at five cents under to flat against July outrights, with only modest dealings.
Heavy Louisiana Sweet/Empire ranged around a 47-50 cents discount, and Midland/WTI was steady at 35-40 cents cheaper than July WTI/Cushing.
West Texas Sour/Midland was sold at $1.50 under, and talked at that value late in the session.
Eugene Island barrels barely moved around a $1.50-55 discount. July WTI/Cushing Postings Plus was at $2.00-05.
